1936-2012 1960-2010 Bill Dixon (1925-2010) was an educator, artist, composer, writer, and jazz musician who played the trumpet, flugelhorn, and piano. In 1968, he became a professor at Bennington College and established the Black Music Division in the 1970s. During his time at Bennington, he taught classes and was the conductor for the Black Music Ensemble. Dixon worked for fifty years as a recording artist, composer, and performer within the avant-garde jazz scene. The Bill Dixon Papers contain material from all facets of Dixon's personal and professional career in music, education, and visual arts. Dixon's music career is represented in the collection through analog and digital recordings of albums, sessions, and performances as well as paper and electronic work files, performance ephemera, and music manuscripts. Dixon's career at Bennington College is reflected in audiovisual recordings and paper files related to Division meetings, class lectures, rehearsals, and musical events. Materials on Dixon's activities outside Bennington College include audiovisual recordings and files related to lectures, appearances, Judson Arts Workshops, the University of the Streets, and his visiting professorship at the University of Wisconsin, Madison. His work as both a visual artist and writer is represented in this collection through artworks, reproductions, exhibition files, publications, and work files for projects including his book L'Opera: A Collection of Letters, Writings, Musical Scores, Drawings, and Photographs (1967-1986). His personal files include photographs, press clippings, interviews, correspondence, and resumes. Some materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Conditions Governing Access
Restricted materials in Series II.A, II.C, and III are notated as such in the record's title. Please contact the Archives with specific questions regarding access to such records. All other materials are open to researchers. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival collections.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Sharon Vogel in March, 2017; the accession number associated with this gift is 2017.022.
Appraisal
Materials containing private student information, including Bennington College mid-term and final student evaluations, class lists, and correspondence discussing student performance, were deaccessioned along with audio recordings of Trustee Meetings and 24 blank compact discs. 103 commercial audiovisual recordings that did not feature Bill Dixon's work were separated from the collection.
Arrangement
This collection is organized into five series. The first two series are arranged into three subseries.
Series I. Music
Subseries I.A. Commercial and Studio Recordings
Subseries I.B. Performance Recordings
Subseries I.C. Sheet Music, Work Files, and Performance Ephemera
Series II. Bennington College
Subseries II.A. Class and Lecture Recordings
Subseries II.B. Performance and Event Recordings
Subseries II.C. Teaching and Administrative Files
Series III. Educational Programs and Appearances
Series IV. Visual and Written Artwork
Series V. Personal Files
Biographical Note
Jazz musician, composer, artist, and educator William (Bill) Robert Dixon was born in Nantucket, Massachusetts in 1925. Around the age of seven, he and his family moved to Harlem, New York. Dixon studied painting at Boston University, the WPA Arts School, and the Art Students League, working in a variety of mediums. Dixon served in the Army during World War II in Germany from 1944-1946, and later studied music at the Hartnett Conservatory of Music from 1946-1951 where he played trumpet, flugelhorn, and piano.
While living in New York in the 1950s, Dixon worked as an international civil servant at the United Nations and helped found the UN Jazz Society. Dixon also worked clubs as a performing musician in Greenwich Village during this time. In 1964, Dixon organized and produced a four-day festival of underexposed talent, the October Revolution in Jazz, including music and discussions, which led to him founding the short-lived cooperative organization of creative improvising New York musicians known as the Jazz Composers Guild.
In 1966, he began a collaborative partnership with dancer and choreographer Judith Dunn, which eventually led to him joining the faculty at Bennington College as a professor. Dixon founded the Black Music Division in the 1970s at Bennington. He assembled and led the Division's faculty and wrote the curriculum until his retirement from Bennington in 1995. While at Bennington, he taught classes in a variety of related subjects including improvisation, composition, and performance. He was director of the Black Music Ensemble. From 1971-1972, Dixon was a visiting professor of Music at the University of Wisconsin, Madison. He retired from Bennington College in 1996.
In addition to his work as an educator, Dixon continued to record music and perform among other improvisational jazz musicians. He played alongside Archie Shepp, Cecil Taylor, William Parker and other musicians of the avant-garde jazz scene. He worked for fifty years as a recording artist, crafting solo music for trumpet, ensemble, dance collaborations, and orchestras. He recorded with record labels RCA, Cadence Jazz Records, and Soul Note, and founded his own publishing company, Metamorphosis Music. In 1967, he composed and conducted a score for the United States Information Agency film The Wealth of a Nation, produced and directed by William Greaves. In 1980, Dixon completed his first tour in Italy, where he would return to record the albums In Italy, Vol I and II, and Considerations, Vol I and II. In 2007, Dixon recorded 17 Musicians in Search of a Sound: Darfur at the New York City Vision Festival to bring attention to the genocide of Sudan's South Darfur region.
Dixon was also an artist working in various mediums including painting, printmaking, drawing, and collage. He often used his visual art on album covers. As an author, he published the book L'Opera: A Collection of Letters, Writings, Musical Scores, Drawings, and Photographs in 1986. He also wrote reviews and articles, and contributed to other books about jazz.
Bill Dixon passed away in 2010.
Born-Digital Access Policies and Procedures
Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted.
An access terminal for born-digital materials in the collection is available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.
Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
Some audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials that have already been digitized are noted in the collection's finding aid and can be requested in our reading room. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact Fales Library and Special Collections, special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596 with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Bill Dixon Papers; MSS 481; box number; folder number or item identifier; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University.
Processing Information
At the time of accessioning, materials were moved into archival housing and described in a spreadsheet to the box level. Born digital items were identified and listed, but not imaged at this time.
In the Summer and Fall of 2022, the collection was arranged and described by two archivists. The collection was divided into series based on record type and arranged intellectually within these series.
In the Fall of 2022, 25 audio reels and 17 audiocassettes were identified as moldy by the Media Preservation Unit. These items are currently isolated from other items by housing them in polyethylene bags with desiccated boards and RH monitor strips. If this strip indicates an RH greater than 50%, the Preservation department should be contacted ASAP. Do not open this packaging without contacting the Preservation Department. 3 audio reels were vacuumed to remove dust. 1 VHS tape and 2 U-matic tapes were reshelled.
730 optical discs 2 hard drives were forensically imaged, analyzed, and arranged. New York University Libraries follows professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity of the content.
Scope and Contents
The Bill Dixon Papers (1936-2012) contains audiovisual, paper, and digital materials documenting Dixon's life and work as a jazz musician, composer, educator, visual artist, and writer.
This collection contains material created during his lifetime career as a jazz musician and composer, particularly the free jazz, experimental music, and avant-garde jazz scenes, dating from the 1960s through 2010. Dixon's large collection of analog and digital audiovisual recordings include performances, rehearsals, radio broadcasts, film soundtracks, and album recording sessions. Paper files support these recordings with handwritten sheet music, correspondence, work files, performance ephemera, and still images of practices, recordings, and performances.
Class curricula, lecture notes, and administrative files document Dixon's tenure as a professor at Bennington College from 1968 to his retirement in 1995. Correspondence, notes, and reports document Dixon's role founding the Black Music Division and his involvement with the Black Music Ensemble. Images portray students, faculty, rehearsals and classes. Audiovisual recordings include Dixon's class lectures (1970s-1990s), music lessons and workshops, student and faculty performances, rehearsals, Black Music Division events, and Division meetings.
This collection also documents Dixon's educational appearances and activities outside of Bennington College. Audiovisual recordings, photographs, and paper files document Dixon's lecture series, panels, and workshops. Notable programs include the Judson Arts Workshops, the University of the Streets, and his visiting professorship at the University of Wisconsin, Madison (Fall 1971 to Spring 1972).
Dixon's work as a visual artist is represented in both original artworks and reproductions of his work, which include photography, collage, printworking, painting, and ink and pencil drawings. The collection also contains tools used in art creation such as printing blocks, an etching plate, and linoleum block sheets. Work files contain correspondence, notes, and images of the creation process and finished works.
As a writer, Dixon produced articles, reviews, book contributions, liner notes for fellow musicians' albums, dating from the 1950s to the 2000s. Many of his writings pertain to his experiences as a jazz musician, compositions, and relationships with other musicians. This collection contains original publications and work files on many of his writings. Work files for his book L'Opera: A Collection of Letters, Writings, Musical Scores, Drawings, and Photographs (1967-1986) contain notes, drafts, mock-ups, correspondence, and the book itself. Also of note are his writings concerning his partnership with the choreographer Judith Dunn, with whom he collaboratived in the 1960s and 1970s.
Audiovisual recordings, photographs, correspondence, datebooks, press clippings, resumes, and scholarly works and interviews provide a profile of his life and work.
Conditions Governing Use
This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder.

Scope and Contents
This series contains analog and digital audiovisual recordings spanning Dixon's musical career, including published albums, features on albums by other artists, film soundtracks, radio broadcasts, recording sessions, solo and ensemble performances, orchestral performances, music festivals, and choreographed collaborations with Judith Dunn. It also contains paper and digital documentation of his work as a musician, including album related work files, music manuscripts, performance ephemera, and annotated reference books.Subseries I.A: Commercial and Studio Recordings45 Linear Feetin 23 flat boxes, 16 record cartons, 3 LP boxes, 1 manuscript box, and 1 cassette box1960-2012
Arrangement
This subseries is arranged chronologically. Undated items are arranged alphabetically at the end of the subseries. Wherever possible, record titles were transcribed directly from audiovisual labels and edited minimally to provide context.
Scope and Contents
This subseries includes recordings from Dixon's published albums spanning his career from the 1960s to 2009; features on albums by other artists, such as Cecil Taylor, Tony Oxley, and Arthur Brooks; music written for films, including Wealth of a Nation (1966); radio broadcasts, including several programs on Columbia University's WKCR that showcased different eras of Dixon's career and celebrated his birthdays; recording sessions for record labels such as RCA, Soulnote, and Cadence Jazz, as well as unissued private recordings; and compilation and demo tapes handmade by Bill Dixon and distributed via Metamorphosis Music.Compilation Tapecuid8713circa 1960s58481_1459

Arrangement
This subseries is arranged chronologically. Undated items are arranged alphabetically at the end of the subseries. Wherever possible, record titles were transcribed directly from audiovisual labels and edited minimally to provide context.
Scope and Contents
This subseries includes recordings of Bill Dixon's musical performances and rehearsals, including solo performances as well as duets, trios, quartets, and sextets with musicians such as Stephen Horenstein, Cecil Taylor, Tony Widoff, Chris Faris, and Ron Stabinsky; choreographed collaborations with Judith Dunn; and large orchestral works. Notable performances include the Newport Jazz Festival (1966), the Autumn Festival in Paris (1976), the Judson Memorial Church Sessions (1964-1967), and the Vision Festival in New York City (2000, 2007). Scope and Contents
This subseries contains paper and digital files related to Bill Dixon as a musician and composer during the 1960s to the 2000s including the creation of his musical albums, original musical works, and performances.
Dixon recorded albums from the early 1960s to 2009. Files related to these albums in this subseries include liner note drafts, recording session notes, album publicity material, and mock-ups and images for albums, some of which contain Dixon's original artwork. This subseries also contains images, ephemera, and program notes related to Dixon's performances as a solo performer and in groups including the 1966 Newport Jazz Festival with dancer Judith Dunn, the orchestra practice for Dixon's original soundtrack for the movie Wealth of a Nation, and University of the Streets performances and rehearsals. Files in this subseries also include information on tours and jazz festivals throughout Italy, Germany, Israel, France, and Canada during the 1980s through 2000s. Musicians Dixon often toured with include Tony Oxley, Cecil Taylor, Mario Pavone, and Laurence Cook.
Dixon's work as a composer is documented through a large collection of handwritten music manuscripts and program notes on individual works including "Autumn Sequences, from A Paris Diary: Fall 1976", "For Franz", "For Cecil Taylor", "Index: A Work for Large Ensemble", "Letters: Round Up the Usual Suspects", "Metamorphosis", and "Winter Song, 1964". A portion of the music manuscripts are untitled and include new compositions and exercises for student ensembles.
The subseries also contains a small collection of files accumulated on the publishing companies Dixon used, including BMI, EMI, IREC, and his own company, Metamorphosis. These files typically include correspondence and reports regarding music rights, royalties, and album production. Heavily annotated reference books on trumpet performance and composition are also in this subseries.
Arrangement
This subseries is arranged chronologically, within groupings of files. Bennington College88.26 Linear Feetin 30 record cartons, 29 flat boxes, 16 manuscript boxes, 4 tall LP boxes, 1 oversize flat box, and 1 flat-file folder.40.26 Gigabytesin 42 digital files.1964-1995, 2005
Scope and Contents
Bill Dixon was a Professor of Music at Bennington College from 1968-1995, where he founded the Black Music Division. Audiovisual recordings, images, and paper files in this series portray class lectures, music lessons, rehearsals, student and faculty performances, and events related to the Black Music Division. This series also includes meeting notes, departmental communications, and founding documents for the Black Music Division.
Conditions Governing Access
Material pertaining to individual student records may be restricted in accordance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). Restricted materials are notated as such in the record's title. Please contact the Archives with specific questions regarding access to such records. All other materials, including student performances with public audiences, are open to researchers.Subseries II.A: Class and Lecture Recordings56.5 Linear Feetin 27 record cartons, 25 flat boxes, 3 LP boxes, and 1 manuscript box1967-1994
Arrangement
This subseries is arranged chronologically. Undated items are arranged alphabetically at the end of the subseries. Wherever possible, record titles were transcribed directly from audiovisual labels and edited minimally to provide context.
Scope and Contents
This subseries contains recordings of Bill Dixon's classes and lectures at Bennington College, including courses such as Elements of Contemporary Composition and Improvisation, Intro to Black Music I and II, Studies in Contemporary Black Music, Black Music Ensemble, and Dance Improvisation. It also includes recordings of private lessons and small music workshops conducted by Bill Dixon at Bennington College.
Conditions Governing Access

If this strip indicates an RH greater than 50%, the Preservation department should be contacted ASAP. Arrangement
This subseries is arranged chronologically. Undated items are arranged alphabetically at the end of the subseries. Wherever possible, record titles were transcribed directly from audiovisual labels and edited minimally to provide context.
Scope and Contents
This subseries includes recordings of concerts and events put on by the Black Music Division at Bennington College, including student performances, senior concerts, faculty concerts, music festivals, and music talks. There are several recordings of performances at "3 Days in October," a 1994 event commemorating the October Revolution in Jazz.
Some recordings of student performances may also be present in Subseries I.B due to limited information; any recordings where student involvement is explicitly noted are located in Series II.B.Compilation Tape: "Index," and Session Footage From "Thoughts" at the Robeson Housecuid368101964, 198569481_1056"Relay" and "Nightfall Pieces" Performed at Bennington Collegecuid38657196842481_2028Tony Ackerman and Bill Dixon Performance at Bennington Collegecuid368461968-196952481_414Improvisation: Bill Dixon and Judy Dunncuid38658December 11, 196955481_1392Bill Dixon and Judy Dunn Music and Dance Performance, Bennington Collegecuid38659December 11, 196954481_1339"Relay" by Bill Dixon and Judy Dunn, Performed at Bennington Collegecuid36873197076481_235180481_2663Electronic RecordsFA_MSS_481_ER_111

Conditions Governing Access
Material pertaining to individual student records may be restricted in accordance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). Restricted materials are notated as such in the record's title. Please contact the Archives with specific questions regarding access to such records. All other materials are open to researchers.
Scope and Contents
This subseries contains material related to Dixon's tenure as a professor at Bennington College, from 1968 to 1995, during which he also founded the Black Music Division (1974). Founding documentation of the Division includes reports, memos, and writings by Dixon. A report from the Black Music Division Visiting Committee dating from 1979 to 1981 provides an overview of the Division and their findings. Division meeting material in this subseries includes audio recordings, minutes, and notes. Dixon's administrative files contain budgets, correspondence, and memos related to the Division. Lecture notes, syllabi, recording transcripts, along with reading and listening lists for Dixon's classes and music lessons are in this subseries. Black Music Division Ensemble and other Bennington College event ephemera and planning files contain programs, promotional posters, correspondence, and notes. Work files for the Black Music Division's short-lived journal, Manuscript: Journal of the New Black Music, contain meeting minutes, writing submissions, correspondence, drafts, and mock-ups from 1974 to 1975. This subseries contains images of rehearsals, performances, college buildings, Bill Dixon, and fellow professors Stephen Horenstein, Sonny Brown, Arthur Brooks, and Nadi Qamar interacting with students. This subseries also contains completed questionnaires, most likely distributed by Dixon to faculty, students, and administrators, to test their knowledge of Black Music from the mid-1940s to the 1970s.Meetings -- Preparation for Spring Music Festivalcuid38751November 16, 196655481_1380Meetings -- A Compilationcuid387521970-198146481_2644Meetings -- Dance Division Meetingcuid38753December 14, 197246481_2625Meetings -- Black Music Festival Meetingcuid38754circa 197353481_1292Meetings -- Faculty Educational Policies Committee Meeting re: Proposal, Black Music Becoming a Division at Bennington Collegecuid38755197346481_2622, 481_2626Meetings -- Black Music Division Meetingcuid38756April, 197346481_2639Meetings -- Black Music Meeting with Bill Dixon, Judith Dunn, Peter Lakowski, and Joanne Gallicuid38757April, 197354481_1331Meetings -- Black Music Division Meetings -- Minutes, Notes, Memos1973-19861001Meetings -- Black Music Division Meetingcuid38758Fall, 197546481_2620Meetings -- Black Music Division Meetingcuid38759Fall, 197546481_2634Meetings -- Faculty Educational Policies Committee and Bill Dixon Meetingcuid38760May 19, 197546481_2623Meetings -- Faculty Meetingcuid38761November 19, 197546481_2630Meetings -- Black Music Division Meetingcuid38762September 20, 197746481_2646Meetings -- Black Music Division Meetingcuid38763197846481_2628RESTRICTED: Meetings -- Administrative Talkcuid38764197819481_072

Scope and Contents
This series includes material on the lectures, workshops, and programming that Dixon engaged in outside of his performing and teaching at Bennington College. Material includes audio and video recordings, and paper and digital files of lectures, workshops, and programming. Notable programs include Judson Arts Workshops and the University of the Streets. This series also includes images, event ephemera, and class lecture plans created during his visiting professorship at the University of Wisconsin, Madison from Fall 1971 to Spring 1972.

Scope and Contents
This series includes material related to Dixon's work as both a visual artist and writer. Original artworks in this series include photography, collage, prints, painting, and drawings. Many of his ink and pencil drawings in this series were rendered on envelopes, concert programs, and Bennington College meeting minutes and memos. Files in this series often contain a combination of artworks, reproductions, and source material stored as they were originally in his studio. Objects in this series relating to the creation of these works include printing blocks, an etching plate, and linoleum block sheets. Dixon would often use printed images of his artworks to create collages. These reproductions and collages are in this series. Exhibition-related files, sketchbooks, and promotional presentation books are also in this series. One notable project was with URDLA (Union Regionale pour le Development de la Lithnographie d'Art) in Lyon, France in January and February 1994 where works on paper created previously by Dixon were produced as lithographs and shown in various exhibitions. This series contains correspondence, notes, and images of this process and the finished works. His artworks were not only shown in exhibitions and sold to collectors, but also used for his album covers. Files on these albums can be found in Series I.C.
Dixon wrote articles, reviews, book contributions, and liner notes for fellow musicians' albums dating from the 1950s to the 2000s. Many of his writings pertain to his experiences as a jazz musician, compositions, and relationships with other musicians. This series contains original publications as well as work files on many of his writings. Work files for his book L'Opera: A Collection of Letters, Writings, Musical Scores, Drawings, and Photographs (1967-1986) contain notes, drafts, mock-ups, correspondence, and the book itself. Scope and Contents
This series contains audiovisual material, and paper and digital files on Dixon's personal life including photographs, correspondence, datebooks, press clippings, resumes, biographical sketches, interviews, and scholarly works on Dixon.
Photographic portraits date from the 1940s to the 2000s and depict Dixon during his childhood and in his military uniform from the 1940s. Images also include his children, partner Sharon Vogel, friends, travel, and interior and exterior views of his home.
Dixon's correspondence in this series is a mixture of both personal and professional, providing a decade by decade view into Dixon's work and relationships dating from the 1960s through the 2000s. Files contain news from friends and fellow musicians, invitations for appearances and performances, album recording issues, event logistics, feedback to journalistic writings, and advice to former students and fans. This series also contains individual correspondence files including family members, collaborators, and friends including Judith Dunn, Milo Fine, Stephen Horenstein, Ted Joans, Tony Oxley, Ben Young, and Jason Zappa. Press clippings in this series cover both his personal and professional life dating from the 1940s to the 2000s, including a special edition of All About Jazz-New York after Dixon's death.
This series also contains files on scholarly works in which Dixon is the subject, and interviews in which Dixon provided information on his work and life. Files typically contain notes, drafts, completed copies of thesis or dissertations, and interview recordings and transcripts. Of note is a project by Bennington College student Steven Albahari from the late 1970s which includes videos of interviews with Dixon and his colleagues as well as recordings of concerts. This series also includes video excerpts of Dixon concerts, appearances, lectures, and other projects, dating from 1965 to 1995.
Dixon's datebooks, address books, resumes, biographical sketches, notes and to-do lists, and membership cards including his New York City cabaret card from 1960 are in this series.Images -- Dixon's Mother, Louise1921-19231711Images -- Bill Dixon1925, 1945-19461712Images -- Bill Dixon1960s-20101713-82099Electronic RecordsFA_MSS_481_ER_422
